reviewText: as usual the translation couldnt possibly live up to the written page..No way it could and as those that know from reading the book, young tho they were, the kids were still way too old. Legal and labor-laws and work-ethics could not possibly allow for the full realization of the book..not to mention the magic needed to get 4-8 yr olds to act like shakesperian poets just isnt gonna happen...better luck herding cats. It's amazing that Enders Game made it to the big screen at all..for that I'm grateful.Big screen movie lengths also are big hinderances, to do it true justice the movie would have likely needed to be twice as long, the target market would no way sit still for a 3-4 hour movie like their dads and uncles that discovered and loved the book back in the 1980's would love to (super-extended directors cut?). I was satisfied enough with what emerged. Not the sci-fi tour-de-force the book was. Average enough and I suppose a good movie experience with a smattering of moral/ethical lessons and human-insights intended for the youth audience in there.I'm admittedly somewhat disappointed with the ending as it seemed to not do well enough to set up and seed the importance of the character 'Bean', skims over the old traits and chaos the earth's nations were falling back into, it also radically re-jiggered Enders events where he located and secured the egg capsule of the formic queen and his finding a new home for its hatching..woefully abreviated and waaay too early in the 'Ender' storyline. Perhaps its an admission that the 'shadow' sequels are likely not going to happen or else have no active plans of production.To be honest I would never expect the following 'Ender' novels to be put on the big screen.. the 'Orson Card' style of story telling from one book to another in this series are huge jumps in both time, characters, mission, and location. As any that have read the series, Enders game bares little to no connection to the next 'Ender-book' "Speaker for the Dead"..the disconnect would throw curveballs that simply will not survive translation to the 'everyman' movie goer.. One truly will have no connection to the other besides the names of the primary characters who at that point are far from being the young pre-pubescent children they were in book-1, no amount marketing and promotion campaign could bridge that gap for the average movie-goer. That said, perhaps it is to be read as an acknowledgement that there would likely be no sequels planned; this opportunity to get this one to the big screen was taken for what it was..and created as a mostly contained and complete story telling, introducing us to this world and characters while leaving no gaping holes to allow for future sequel speculation or ready expectation. A relatively tidy experience overall.Again..very glad it made it to the screen and did a decent enough job of not screwing the entire pooch as generally happens with book-to-movie adaptations..If another OSC book is ever under consideration for adaption to the big screen..any guesses on what I'd love to see?
summary: Glad it made it to the big screen...

reviewText: For those purchasing Ender's Game on Blu-Ray, here are the special features: Aside from the iTunes Digital Download and Ultraviolet Downloads; you get audio commentary from the director, Gavin Hood; an "Inside the Mind Game" featurette; a Behind the Scenes Making of "Ender's Game" called "Ender's World," and deleted/extended scenes with optional audio commentary from Hood.Now on to my movie review: I read Ender's Game, 13 years ago as a freshman in high school. While the movie adaptation of Ender's Game condenses a lot of what happened in battle school, omits a lot of the politics that was happening on Earth, and glosses over the friendship between Ender and Bean, I was impressed with how the movie retained the essence of the book. Probably the most enjoyable part of the movie was seeing their interpretation of Battle School. Given how advanced technology is today, at least compared to 2001, the special effects were better than I imagined.In truth, I believe that the entire Ender's Universe would have been better served as a mini-series or a TV show, especially if it focused on the Ender's Shadow series as I think the general public would have related better with what was happening on EARTH than in Space. The film itself, wasn't very accommodating for a movie franchise or even a sequel, even though it did leave things "open-ended" enough.A huge round of applause should be given to the casting. The casting of Asa Butterfield as Andrew 'Ender' Wiggin, the titular 'hero,' is perfection. He played Ender's conflicting emotions, vulnerabilities and viciousness with a sincere conviction beyond someone his age should be able to portray. He truly is talented young man and I hope he continues acting because his future and career are bright. I was completely okay with them aging up all the characters, because let's be honest, it'd be difficult to find a believable precocious young actor to portray a 6 year old and then to a 12/13 year old commander.My favorite scenes involved him commanding his jeesh or confronting his enemies, including even Graff. Some of the best scenes in the movie was solely just Asa's Ender going head to head with Harrison Ford's Colonel Graff. Speaking of, Harrison Ford is perfect as Colonel Graff, I think if the movie had been a success and a potential sequel was in the making, he'd have the necessary gruff kindness to play Bean's confidante. And while the gender change in Anderson threw me for a second, I love Viola Davis, she's just a fantastic actress and her Anderson is a great reminder that these soldiers in Battle school are in fact kids, who have to return to "normal" life after the war. And another brilliant nugget of casting was Nonso Anozie as Sergeant Dap. I couldn't help shout out "Game of Thrones!" whenever he appeared on screen.I remember back in 2001, the book was always stuck in perpetual rumors of being in pre-production or casting, with names like Haley Joel Osment being thrown around as possible candidates to play Ender. 12 years later, I think the movie was made and released at the right time with the right cast, just the circumstances around the book being 28 years old and Orson Scott Card's personal statements, mired the movie's potential success. If it weren't for the boycotting, the movie could have done better, and maybe the marketing could have pushed a near 30 year old book better, but it's truly a pity most high schoolers aren't required to read this book anymore and most kids these days don’t know much about the series.Which was why it was also such a pity that Bean wasn't more significant in the movie adaptation. I had read that Orson Scott Card’s initial drafts to the movie adaptation of Ender’s Game were to have it centered more on Ender and Bean’s friendship. THIS WOULD HAVE BEEN THE RIGHT DIRECTION. But the director preferred pushing Ender and Petra’s friendship, which is fine, but it killed any potential opportunity for a true Shadows sequel, which in my opinion would have made better movies. Plus, Bean gets Petra in the end. Has nine children with her and he is the love of her life.Part of the problem I had with the other books in Ender's series after Ender's Game is that Ender's story was interesting because not only of the war he ends, but the people IN the book he meets. The afore mentioned Bean and Petra, Alai, Dink, Shen, Graff, etc. These were all his friends and allies that don't appear in the sequels (aside from Ender in Exile - written AFTER Bean's Shadow sequels), so why would anyone care about them?The truth is, restoring the Formics' world is admirable of Ender, especially how Ender's guilt consumed him, but reading about it? Not as interesting. Learning about battle school and how Ender dealt with the pressures of the school, his actions in defending himself, and the war was interesting. But basing a franchise around his travels in space with the Formics, just isn't appealing.I think this is why Ender's Shadow would have made a better "franchise" starter. You start it with Ender's Game, introducing both Ender and Bean, blending both Ender's Game and Ender's Shadow. Then continue on to the beginning of Ender in Exile, then Shadow of the Hegemon, Shadow Puppets, Shadow of the Giant, and then back to Ender in Exile and end it with Ender's travels in space.What's done is done. This is a great "companion" movie to go with the novel, Ender's Game. As a huge fan of the Ender Shadow's series and the book Ender's Game, I thought everybody did the best they could with the budget and time constraints. Again, I already mentioned that it's a pity they didn't go with Card's initial draft of the movie, but what's done is done. I only hope in the future sometime, the books will be made into a miniseries as the stories and characters themselves are certainly deserving.
summary: Great Cast, A Decent Book to Movie Adaptation

reviewText: This was an interesting movie, my feelings about it continue to evolve. There is some truth in the concept that kids are more proficient at gaming technology than adults and applying that premise to real life military situations is plausible. That said it isn't very believable  the way 14 year old  Ender rises above bullying and other childhood obstacles and rockets through the ranks to become a great military leader against earths greatest enemy which threatens humanities extinction. If you get past the ridiculousness of all that it is entertaining. Sort of a remake of the Star Troopers movies idea us against the bugs. The ending is another "we have to end this movie fast so let's come up with something quick" moment. Dumb!Do not buy, rent once!

reviewText: Ender's Game had a lot working for it. There was mostly solid performances and some good special effects, with a decent plot.However, as someone who never read Ender's Game the book, I have to admit that the problem I had with the movie is that it felt like at the end of the film, I was watching an entirely different type of movie than I had for the first part..Through about the first 4/5ths of the movie, I was watching a film that seemed to combine two distinct types of films: a coming of age a story and a kick tail sci fi action film. The Coming of Age story was particularly marked as Ender progressed. He gained the respect of peers and even a sergeant who swore he would never salute Ender. He grew and became a leader as his true potential was brought to the fore.  While there were indications that the Graff was rushing to violence, Ender showed enough character, compassion, and decency that you felt he'd do the right thing once in command.***Spoilers***And then he commits genocide by blowing up the alien planet, after being tricked by the adults who were using actual ships in his last simulation. As a viewer, I felt like I'd suffered a bait and switch.  While there were some darker scenes, nothing really suggested that the whole alien threat was in the mind of the adults. Nothing suggested what would happen. Colonel Graff  looked like the tough and determined Coach/Authority figure pushing our young hero to greatness not the crazy paranoid guy who wanted to go to total war with aliens just in case.The 30 day countdown shown in one scene made even the most extreme behavior to prepare Ender seem okay because after all it was 30 days until the alien bug apocalypse. Apparently if you read the book, you'd know it was 30 days until we invaded the aliens, but again that's not how it looked to me.To be fair, it did seem the adults didn't actually plan on Ender blowing up the alien world. They were more like, "Hmm. Okay, that works."The adaptation from the book is at times sloppy. For example, while we don't know the aliens language, we do know the name of the species. How? Also, why the heck did the aliens who wanted peace spend decades making no effort to make amends with Earth while thousands of Earth ships set themselves to invade, instead opting to contact the young boy who was to lead the forces against the planet and speaking to him in vague dream imagery. And why the heck did they promote a kid to Admiral, put him on a shuttle , and send him on his merry way?I've read some reviewers suggest that this should have been made into two movies to provide more detail and explanation, but if they told the story the same way, I would have been more annoyed to watch two movies that end with our hero being duped into genocide.Based on box office results, this is probably the only film we'll see in this series and it's quite a pathetic ending. The only thing the ending does do is make you empathize with Ender. Just as he was told the simulation would be one thing, the movie told us it was one thing until the very end when it became something else entirely in a way that's not clever, but really annoying.
summary: Bait and Switch at the End

reviewText: Turning books into movies must be difficult. Change too much and you are at risk of angering the fans and change too little and the movie might not flow that well. Ender's Game leans somewhere towards the latter of that spectrum, but it still works fairly well as a film in its own right. Despite not liking some aspects of the book, the Battle School section is fantastic, so I had high hopes for this film. Luckily, I wasn't too disappointed.The movie does a good job of explaining the story quickly to newcomers without boring readers. Basically, aliens called Formics have attacked Earth twice, and the last time humanity almost lost except for Mazer Rackham's heroic (and mysterious) sacrifice. Now, the Formics are attacking again and the government is training children to take them down, with the war relying on training a particular boy named Ender Wiggin to be the leader.Ender's Game the book travels at a fairly quick pace; Ender's Game the movie speeds by even faster, which is both a good and bad thing. The pacing feels perfect in the last half-hour or so, but during the Battle School part (as I mentioned as my favorite part of the book) feels like it is missing some crucial scenes. When (mild spoilers) Ender gets control of his own army at the school, he says he will make them the best. And then all of the sudden we cut to just one battle and one battle only that results in Ender leaving to go to Command School. The book perfectly captured the feeling that Ender was rising to the top, but somehow the movie mostly misses this.Although I would have liked to have seen more, the Battle Room scenes are neat (basically zero-gravity laser tag) and the movie strengthens again near the end where a twist that will likely surprise those who haven't read the book is executed perfectly. The ending is thought-provoking and handled very well, perhaps even better than the book did it. All of the acting performances are great, with Asa Butterfield as Ender being a particularly strong choice. The music is also very impressive, and visually the film looks great.Outside of a few small but glaring problems with the film's pace and a few pieces feeling like they are missing, this film is what any fan could have hoped for from the book and stands on its own as a good science-fiction adventure. Those into the genre should definitely check it out.

reviewerName: Allen M. Lewis "the original book worm"
reviewText: Refers to Blu-ray version of Ender's game.I am always a bit wary when one of my favorite books is turned into a movie. Oftentimes the translation from print to visual performance does not work.  I am happy to say that the movie adaptation of Orson Scott Card's classic exceeded my expectations. I think the main reason is that the adult supporting cast: Harrison Ford, Sir Ben Kingsley, and Viola Davis gave such strong performances.I also agreed with the idea of casting older children to play the parts of Ender and his compatriots.  In the book, by the time they reached Command School, they were teenagers, so to have them be so in a two-hour compression was not jarring.  This is different from the approach taken by the Harry Potter series where Harry and his friends grew up with each film.  That choice was really not available in this case.The sets, the music, and the technical aspects were appropriate to the story line and did not distract.
summary: A very good translation from a book to a movie

reviewText: (The director that had the balls to tackle this one that is.)This is a visually impressive movie. It's also very flat and lacking in the intense emotion the story contains. I must give credit to the folks that translated this into a movie. They did the best job that could have been done. Don't bother watching it unless you have read the book. There are only two possible responses to this movie; 1. You didn't already know the story and have just watched a very  bland and puzzling scifi flick that didn't have much of a point or 2. You are knashing your teeth and pulling out your hair in agony because the story mostly followed the book in a valium induced coma sort of way.  You cry a single tear of grief because you realized about twenty seconds before the end credits start rolling that this movie will never ever shift out of granny gear.  So if you read the book and you had the above mentioned emotional response at least your emotion filled in the gaping hole left by the film's lack in that department.On a side note to the set designers, the battle room and many of the other sets were just visually waaaay too busy. (Why in the heck are the medical staff wearing nurse outfits from the 60s complete with pillbox nurse caps???) Lastly, know that the actors all did a fine job. Harrison Ford and Ben Kingsly are 2 of my all time favorites.

reviewText: Like all other sci fi writers since Asimov, Orson Scott Card, it seems has adopted and adapted many ideas from the Lensman series and Smith's space opera novels from the 1930s and 1940s.  If the movie is faithful to what this author wrote in the original novel then indeed the battle concepts, strategies come from the Lensman series (6 volumes).  If all of this gushing is over Card's novels then I highly recommend Smith's amazing ouvre.
summary: A rip-off of e. e. doc. smith's The Lensmen series?

reviewText: Astonished by the story and the young star. This movie thrilled and fascinated me. I will be reading the book because the movie characterization of Ender (played by Asa Butterfield) shows an extraordinary person not easily, convincingly, found anywhere in cinema; a child's intelligence disciplined to the degree that we see a boy who truly blurs the line between child and adult. I figure it can only happen in a writer's mind and am grateful to the director for aiming so well at the writer's concept. Even if the question of age is not on target for some, the result raises eyebrows and makes age and maturity more of a mystery than I ever thought possible.Ender is obviously a child, but is gifted with a self-awareness that no child possesses. His military severity, coupled with great empathy and compassion, makes him much more than his age. But his innocent face begs the question, what is appropriate or inappropriate to have a child do, even at our country's most desperate hour? As if fighting and war are somehow more moral than any number of crimes against children. Of course, I value this movie for the way it uses fiction to make me think and not to get all wrapped up in serious issues. But I find it amazing that the boy-man concept could be brought to the screen so perfectly, so intelligently, in the performances of all involved. It's haunting and this is definitely one for my collection.

reviewText: It may still become a miniseries. At least they need to make "Speaker for the Dead" ; then we can see a better balanced rendition of what Orson Scott Card is trying to say to us.As with many movies there is not enough time to portray or even imply what the book tells us. Tee best we can hope for is a good reflection and not let the movie change the story for its own ends. This is one of those movies that tried in the time allotted to give you not only the feel but to put in as many details as possible.The choice of actors did a pretty good match to the characters. The graphics did not overwhelm the story. The background music did not washout the dialog. Unfortunately the version I watched did not have a voice over commentary to add to the experience. We view the story as a third party and never really get into anyone's mind.To many readers it will never be justified. To people that have not read the book it may be obscure. But at least they did not try to make a different story out of it. I am trying to restrain myself from comparing this film to classic sci-fi stories. To the movie's credit they did not dwell on the technology. The story here is about people and societies that just happen to take place in the future.Basic story is that it looks like we have been attacked a nearly annihilated. Our only recourse is to do unto others before they do it unto us. We do not know their intentions but take no chances. In the military we are always taught that no two wars are the same; we can train but must be flexible and initiative. The primes here are that children are more flexible and amendable to new environments.We are left with a moral question. This question will be better developed in the next book and hopefully the next film.Ender's Game and Philosophy: The Logic Gate is Down (The Blackwell Philosophy and Pop Culture Series)
summary: Would have made a great miniseries.

reviewText: This movie is poorly written and poorly directed, both by Gavin Hood.  Characters routinely announce their motivations, the same bit of exposition is repeated no less than three times in the first 20 minutes of the movie (the repetition is a minor plot point later on, but it's a completely unnecessary one), and we get lingering shots of scenery without any real point while the rest of the movie feels like it's rushing to get through major plot points as fast as it can.  Harrison Ford looks and sounds tired, but I don't think that's a character choice.  The second half of the movie is much, much better than the first, but that's just because the first half is laughably bad.  And half of the good half is just a setup for the sequel they were surely hoping to make.I thought I'd be happy enough with this movie if they just had some cool scenes of space paintball like in the book.  Turns out there's not much of that here, and what is here sometimes abandons the "Ender is a tactical genius" aspect that is the core of the book for a more conventional "Look at how well he can shoot with a gun in each hand!" approach.  They do have one good battle school scene that feels like it could have come straight from the book, but those 5 minutes don't make up for what comes before them.I don't want to come across as one of those "They ruined my favorite book!" types.  I don't actually care if they change the book, as long as the changes make a good movie.  I think some of the changes here would have worked better if they had gone further with them.  Ender's siblings, for instance, get such little screen time and characterization that the movie would have been better off cutting them completely; as it is, they're just a way to visualize a ham-handed theme.All in all, I only really enjoyed about 20 minutes of this movie.  The rest just felt like it was keeping me from the fun parts.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had read the book on Orson Scott Card's web site last summer and thought wow, this is intense, dramatic, and compelling.  A group of gifted young women and men are selected for an academy to lead the fight against an alien race.  They are very young and have to advance dramatically both mentally and physically.  This is about what it's like at that training camp and the story of one young man, Ender, who somehow pulls everything within him together.  Imagine just for a few minutes that we in the United States could do that with our educational and career systems.  After excelling by beating many, many other opponents and their squads at the training games, like mock warfare, he is sent off to a command kind of school and has to leave his family and all the friends he knows.  At command school he is pitted against other opponents who are hand selected along with their teams.  Finally he goes to what he thinks is the final stage of training, but it is not just training.  Here I won't spoil what happens, but i enjoyed the struggle within this young man and his fierce will along with his ability to attract a strong team around himself.  The aliens end up being much different than we think and Ender has a gift for mind-reading.  The special effects are outstanding.  The tension building up within him and in the story is striking.  There is a series of books following this first book in the series too.  You should read those too.  I didn't remember the ending of the movie from reading the first book.  Perhaps I missed something.  The movie is more hopeful than I had imagined by reading the reviews.  I don't know, but it seems like some of the reviewers did not watch the movie all the way through.  If you are a science fiction fan, don't miss this one.  It is very special.  I think perhaps what some people didn't like was that the story is driven so much by the promise and mental flexibility and learning capabilities of very young men and women.  I wonder, is that a message about our future?  Do we need to be much more open minded to really understand life and so that we are not so judgmental.  The movie left me with many deep questions.  Very, very enjoyable and stimulating.
summary: Enders Game; Many reviewers just hate scifi; I always add an extra star or point. The adventure & futurist allure --Love it

reviewText: Like many reviewers I have enjoyed the book and have reread it on several occasions and obviously movie adaptations are always tricky as back story is harder to get accross. I'm not going to get I to a detailed content review as others have done that but rather list the pros and cons this movie had IMO:Pros- superbly cast for the most part- stunning visuals- follows the book close enough without making up too much new material- captured the spirit of battle school and the moral conflicts of sending children to war- excellent acting on the child actors partCons- backstory doesn't come through enough- several important character developments not covered (Peter/valentine comes to mind mostly, but also Bean, Petra, Alai come of as underdeveloped sidekicks)- too much emphasis on action, too little emphasis on the politics of the mock battles which made the book interesting- timeline too compressed to show real depth which I guess is a concession to the issues with the physical development of the child actors- felt at times like a visual companion to the book, I.e. You need to read the book to actually fully 'get' the movie, then its great, otherwise it feels slightly disjointed...YMMV, but for me the pros outweighs the cons and I enjoyed the movie...

reviewText: It's been some years since I read Ender's Game. (I read the first four books in the series, the first two of which were outstanding, the next two pretty good but not enough for me to continue with the series as Card wrote more.) Watching this movie, most of the details came back, and I found that the visuals of the movie felt true to what I'd pictured when reading. It was very enjoyable to see these wonderful scenes come to life, and it's great that modern special effects have a reached the point where this is possible.There were a few aspects that could have been improved. The Battle School training sequences were good but lacked the thrill that the book evoked. Ender's relationships with his siblings was underdeveloped in the film. But overall I felt the story was well told, well acted, and never boring.It's a shame that Card's personal beliefs affected the reception of this film. I didn't know about them until the movie came out, and part of why I didn't know is because the story is not about his personal bigotry. For myself, I've chosen to approach the story entirely on its own merits, not to pass judgment on anyone who made it. Others may make a different choice. Ender's Game was a landmark science fiction story, and I think this is an excellent film adaptation.
summary: Excellent Adaptation of a Classic Novel

reviewText: **** Possible Spoilers Below!!! ****If you loved the book this movie is based on I can understand your reticence to go see it. My brother hasn't seen it because some people say it's worth it and some people say it is way off the mark. Well, I saw it because my brother introduced me to the books right when this movie came into theaters. I didn't have quite the attachment that my brother does, but I was very obsessed (to the point where I reread the book while waiting for Speaker For The Dead to arrive from the library rather than start another book and have since December of '13 purchased nearly all the books within the Enderverse) with the story told by Orson Scott Card.I found that the movie cut corners from the story. This is to be expected considering much of the drama of the book stems from things that are moralistic and difficult to portray visually. To me, the movie seemed to be flying at a million miles an hour, but this too is to be expected. It took me several nights to get the same story, albeit a more detailed story, read while the movie took almost two hours to shrink as much of the story down to it's most constituent parts so that the essence of the story was still there. It certainly helped to use many lines or portions of dialogues directly from the book itself. I don't know if this book to movie line transfer is common, as this is the first book I've read that made it onscreen, but for me, a lover of the book, this really connected the two mediums.There are some liberties with the story too. Ender seems to be about 12 - 15 throughout the whole movie, so his fight with Stillson occurred not when he was six, nor did Graff collect him when he was six. Probably depicting such young kids in a militaristic setting would have been upsetting for many parents. Also, the Battle School timeline was shortened, despite that being a significant amount of the content of the original story. So those are some of the main differences (there are a few more but I don't want to give too many spoilers) that I noticed between the book and the movie.The only thing I didn't like was the fact that they tattooed Mazer Rackham's face in the movie, saying that he is Maori. I don't recall that from the book at all, and see no point to having Ben Kingsly paint his face as such. But Orson Scott Card was credited as a producer and so was his "Ender Buddy" Aaron Johnston so maybe they know something we don't, or maybe YOU all know something that I don't. Please fill me in if the latter is true.Fantastic movie. Deviates from book a little, but not so much it makes you hate the director or the original author.
Title: N/A

reviewText: .[FOR THOSE WHO WANT A SIMPLIFIED REVIEW, JUST ZIP TO THE FINAL FOUR PARAGRAPHS. THERE ARE NO SPOILERS.]Just about anybody who has read Ender's Game knows what to expect when it comes to this movie, and it is my guess that these are the people who comprise the majority of the audience. In other words, the screenwriter (and director) Gavin Hood's decision to let us in early on a key element of the surprise ending is probably a wise one; it is now only Ender himself, and his youthful comrades, who remain in the dark. Though a good deal of the book's shocking ending depended on this factor, the film, pointedly, does not. (NOTE: Even author Orson Scott Card himself--who tried to write several unsuccessful screenplays for this movie himself--conceded its seeming impossibility in this regard).Now, as to whether ENDER'S GAME does service to the novel, that's a question I suppose only the box office will ultimately reveal. For me, I found the movie to be a lavish but watered down adaptation. True, making movies out of books is usually a process prone to reduction, but I felt the movie lacked so much that it affected my appreciation of it as the character-driven story that the novel depicted so well.  And Ender's development as a character is key to the success of the movie.Not to reveal anything--which I won't--but ENDER'S GAME the novel is a story told through several narratives, much like another great young adult novel calledI AM THE CHEESE, by Robert Cormier. The narrative threads help us understand the fabric of characterization and plot that one single narration could not have achieved. ENDER'S GAME the novel was spectacularly successful at this--so much so that the novel has sold millions of copies, has been translated into over 30 languages, has won the Hugo and the Nebula, and on and on. (It's unfortunate that it has been tarred by the furor caused by author Orson Scott Card's negative views on homosexuality, particularly dealing with same-sex marriage, but that--and WORSE offenses--he engineered himself.)But it is ENDER'S GAME the movie that is the subject here, and whether IT works or not. While it has all the trimmings of high-caliber acting, extraordinary special effects, and certainly a compelling plot, it came up short at affecting the grand story told by the novel. Where the novel succeeded--and so well, in fact, that it is suggested reading in U.S. Marine Corps training school--is in the details of Ender's training, and in particular in his ingenious response to the dilemmas dealt him by his battle school commanders.And as anyone familiar with the book will tell you, it's in this regard thatENDER'S GAMEthe novel is so compelling. Ender's ability to think his way out of difficult situations makes for fascinating reading, and Card deserves credit for the brilliant strategies he invoked. The complex conflicts he faced were not just military ones--for instance, he was not only repeatedly bullied by his jealous fellow students, but he also used his growing success as a tool to force concessions from his trainers--they were understandable and progressive, and the novel reported his steady coming to terms with his hostile environs in a step-by-step manner.You see, the world is facing its second set of attacks by a culture it barely defeated the first time around, and there's no denying that this time it is likely to face overwhelming destruction. Ender is one of the latest round of cadets being rushed through training school in a desperate attempt to find someone, ANYONE who can think like their enemy, and use that empathy to defeat them. The older tacticians have been too set in their ways to accomplish such a task--the secret, they know, lies in the young, and Ender is the best of the lot. In fact, he's the best anyone has EVER seen.Yet in the movie this prowess is displayed so briefly that it's no more than a highlight reel...it's like watching a three-hour football game in a hour. I really felt the movie's brevity in the scenes concerning the computer program designed to bring out his inner demons, and again in the revealing progression of games played within the weightless Battle Dome. It was there his genius really revealed itself, and his spectacular outside-the-box strategies came across so well.While the acting was of a high caliber--particularly that of Viola Davis and Ben Kingsley as a major interested in Ender's psychology and a singular hero of the last war, respectively--and the special effects were grand, I felt let down by the short shrift the movie gave Ender's tactical growth.  Again, this is no small factor--it is, in fact, what makes the book so magnificent. And it just wasn't really there for me.So, while I feel that the movie made good entertainment, I do not believe it was a compelling movie for the same reasons as its source material. As such, I only give it a three...maybe higher if you have not read the book and are only there to see razzle and dazzle. In that case, you're on your own.
summary: Lots of Glamor, But Lacks What Makes the Novel So Great

reviewText: This was a pretty good movie,probably steered toward younger people that are game addicted and or  like annimation.Sorry to sound old here but the draw here for me was Harrison Ford and Ben Kingsley,being they were important to me with Star Wars,Blade Runner and Ghandi(Ghandi being not an action movie but well acted) and others in that era.The concept here is that this brainiac kid is plucked out of his class for having razor sharp leadership skills and solutions to problems and advanced to defeat the latest threat to the colonies in from Earth from the "Buggers" an Insectoid species going after the "queen" bug.Harrison Ford playes a "drill sargeant" type to find his next leader because the last "millitary kickbutt leader"(Ben Kingsley) was thought to be killed in the last big battle to defeat the bugs.It turns out he wasn't killed but went into hiding on a distant location,maybe I'm wrong about the details but you get the concept.The kid goes through "cosmic boot camp" and defeats his opponents in a series of trails and winds up in charge of the military forces,and what he thinks is his final trial which is a video game defeats the bugs and gets the queen to save everyone.Actually it is reality and he really does kill the enemy(and a lot of his troops)to gain victory,the command has fooled him into doing the job and he freaks out.Everything works out in the end even though he feals used in the process!He gets the bugs and the pretty girl in the end and becomes the next"millitary kickbutt leader".From what I read in a movie description this was a book from 1977 and I guess finally CGI got advanced enough to do this type of movie.I don't mean to be prejudgiced toward "gamers" but the treand toward "action through CGI sequences" has become so often because of cheaper production costs in hollywood I miss real acting!Maybe CGI has got to be so good that there is no need for actual acting?Anyway this is aimed toward gamers,its actually a pretty good movie!This reminds me of "Starship Troopers" in a way,and in that movie it was the "brain bug" that was the thing to get!They plug in a couple of good old actors to make it more respectable and draw in old farts like me!!haha!!check it out,its a good way to kill a couple of hours!!Hey look at last years big space drama "Gravity",it was almost all CGI and made a ton of money(no acting awards)but a lot of technical awards and etc.Maybe someday there will all CGI movies and no need for actual actors anymore,like Jim Cameron said in jest on the set of "avatar" a few years ago(that movie made a billion),it would sure be a lot cheaper then paying a bunch of high price actors,haha!!just kidding!!who knows what the future will be?The Oscars seem to still favor an actual acting movie!I suppose Sci-Fi will be in this CGI trend?From Star Wars on this is the way its going,watch and enjoy!!This movie is worth 3 maybe 3 1/2 stars at best!
summary: A good movie for game addicted people....I didn't read the book!!

reviewText: If you consider how well educated science fiction viewers are when watching effects, graphics, stunts, photography, et. all, plus the microscopes brought out when the movie is based on a book they're fond of, I was surprised when I heard that this movie was being made.I was happy to see that the movie is not exactly like the book. The written story is much more violent as I recall, and I'm glad that kids got to see this. And a single movie would have trouble covering everything in the long book.Ender's Game, the movie, is well cast. Asa Butterfield was a great fresh-faced version of Ender, and the adult actors were wonderful. I had some doubts about a couple of the cadets, but I found nearly all of them believable toward the end. The group tactics exercises were a lot of fun to watch, in fact I enjoyed all of the enhancements!Everything came together and worked for me in this movie. It was a huge undertaking and I think the right choices were made to tell the story.The special features on this video were great, by the way!

reviewText: I remember "Ender's Game" making the rounds at the lunch table in my freshman year of high school. As each student in our clique of slightly gothic and artistic individuals finished novels in the series, we passed them on to the next person. So, I eagerly awaited the release of this film after seeing the trailer during my last trip to the theater.The story about a young prodigy, chosen as a sole commander of the earth's battle forces, is presented in much a similar fashion as in the novel. Asa Butterfield is Ender, the protagonist, who trains to lead the earth forces. Harrison Ford is his, sometimes, none-too-gentle superior who steers him in this endeavor as General Graff. I feel that in the novel, Ender is a much stronger character than the one portrayed in this film version. However, I've come to like the slightly more subtle Ender that might contribute less to deluded feelings of grandeur or overestimating one's ability to succeed in real life. Admittedly, after watching two hours of Ender's Game, I came out of the theater feeling like I could stop traffic with my eyes closed while waving popcorn from the machine, whimsically, through the air, across the lobby, out through the door, and into my mouth. Some moments in the novel and the movie are just magical like that!I had three friends with me, and after getting a feel for their opinion afterwards, I think this movie is best suited to us sci-fi, fantasy, and "geeky" types. I would have loved for all of my friends to have enjoyed Ender's Game as immensely as I did, but I suppose I can't turn them all. ;)
summary: Entertaining but lacking the strength of the original main character

Title: N/A

reviewText: “Ender's Game”, a 1985 novel from Orson Scott Card, is the subject of a new film and director Gavin Hood (X:Men Origins: Wolverine). It is a science-fiction action film with an uncharacteristic premise. It is uncharacteristic in the sense that as a science-fiction action film, it is less eventful and more thoughtful. Andrew “Ender” Wiggin (Asa Butterfield) is an extremely gifted kid with the mentality for success in battle. He is closely watched by Colonel Graff (Harrison Ford) and quickly moved up the ranks of a futuristic military academy.An alien species called the 'formics' or in the book, 'the buggers', are threatening earth's existence and desperate moves are needed to be made. “Ender's Game” does have elements that are similar to two films in my opinion, but seeing as though the book came out in 1985, those films appear to be inspired by the book. Those movies are “Full Metal Jacket” (1987) and “Starship Troopers” (1997). The film focuses on the training of military recruits preparing for war against bugs and it makes a broad statement about war and its effect on the human condition.This is easily the best thing that Harrison Ford has done in years and his performance is only bolstered by the performance of sort of unknown Asa Butterfield. Butterfield encompasses everything needed to portray a complex and challenging role. Maybe his previous performance in a rare gem like “The Boy in the Striped Pajamas” prepared him for such an emotional and deep character. Much is placed upon the shoulders of the teenager Ender Wiggin and Butterfield was flawless at bringing you into an inner-turmoil that many times can only be described in a book.I wondered why “Ender's Game” was not a summer blockbuster release because the effects are well done and the movie looked like a blockbuster type thing, but now that I've viewed it, I understand its release completely. This isn't a blockbuster release type film. This is a thoughtful film, more suitable for Oscar season and a more thoughtful movie-goer. The movie challenges you to question things and rethink things, just as its lead character does, separating him from others.The ending of the film seem to be rushed and thrown together; most undoubtedly to prepare this film for a possible franchise of films, but that would be the only thing that I disliked about it. Not that the ending was bad, but in a film that was already near 2-hours, what happened in its final minutes, to be done properly would have required at least another 20 or 30 minutes that the creator decided to forgo. Otherwise, “Ender's Game” is loaded with solid performances and intelligence.

reviewText: I'm not well-versed in sci fi "lore", but after I read what Harrison Ford said about the themes of military ethics this movie addresses, I wanted to see it.  I'm glad I did.  Thankfully, the pace moves quickly and doesn't dwell on moods and emotions or weird aspects of the sci fi technology.  Asa Butterfield is very good as the young actor who plays Ender, the boy/early teen prodigy who is being trained to lead an invasion against a former enemy.  The enemy is a race of aliens who had fought against earth about 50 years before.  Ender has to confront the "establishment's" modus operandi:  Is it right to attack a group that has been minding its own business because there had been a previous war and you don't want a future attack from them?  This is very relevant to America's foreign policy.  While I believe preemptive war is sometimes necessary when the designs of the enemy are very clear--think of how much better off Europe would have been if Britain had intervened just one year earlier against Hitler, whose intent was unmistakable and who was doing a massive military buildup--there is no justification for war against former enemies that no longer have aggressive intent, or who just want to have access to resources in their surroundings.  I would hope people would see that this is very relevant to Israel's attitude toward the Palestinians, most of whom are peaceful, and that there is a difference between xenophobia (hostility to foreigners, racial apartheid) and being wisely involved in preventing terrorist attacks.  Another thing that struck me thematically was the manipulation of Ender's mind through virtual reality/simulated reality.  When I experienced what I consider the golden age of computer games, in the 90s, they were engaging, but in subsequent years, they have gotten much more realistic and overblown in their effect on the mind.  I am deeply concerned about the psychological effect they have on people, desensitizing them to real-life catastrophes, and whether intentionally or not, this theme is explored in Ender's Game as young Ender plays a game on his electronic device to develop his tactical thinking skills.The other thing that hit me thematically was the exploitation of children.  I felt I was witnessing the corruption of youth as the story of Ender and his classmates developed.  Adolf Hitler was the first leader to so successfully take control over every child's mind, because he had more powerful media than ever before in history.  His Germany was very well connected technologically, better than the extensive Soviet Union.  That made for a very hierarchical, very well controlled training program for the entire society.  Like the Nazis, the military training school in Ender's Game incessantly pushes the children to be merciless and focused only on their mission.  This develops camaraderie for them, but also a coldness toward anyone outside their race.  They also have intense power play against their peers and are forbidden to communicate with their families back on earth.  Hitler Youth and League of German Girls camping events, and the Nuremberg rallies, were how the Nazis brainwashed children.  They isolated them from every other influence, and made them see themselves as no more than pawns for the larger agenda.  Harrison Ford's character, who is not exactly a villain but no hero, either, has boxed himself into an unethical outlook on warfare, and is convinced that children are born to further the collective interest, like Hitler and the other Nazi leaders.  Hitler himself didn't think his agenda was all about him, but about serving his cause of racial purity, a perverted and deeply hateful form of nationalism.  Yet even though the western world is less nationalistic since WWII, this kind of thinking is still dangerously alive, including in America.  Many are convinced that the ends justify the means, and that if the goal is worthy, you don't have to follow constitutional procedures.  That applies to all kinds of government takeovers and surveillance programs.As I have just described, I see many themes that are valuable in this movie.  Also, the special effects blew me away.  I loved the battle arena where war games are practiced, kind of like a game of laser tag.  And at the end of the movie, there is still hope even though there have been sorrowful consequences.  It is similar to Dr. Seuss's The Lorax, but so as to not reveal too much, I end there.
summary: Worth seeing - themes of collective thinking/brainwashing, corruption of youth, & preemptive war, along w/ great special effects

reviewText: Despite any misgivings concerning Orson Scott Card's personal beliefs about controversial subjects, his novel "Ender's Game" (TOR, 1985) often shows up in the top 2 or 3 titles of the most loved books among Science Fiction readers. The original novel won both the Hugo and Nebula Awards for Best Novel, not an easy feat since few have won both awards for the same book. ("Dune" by Frank Herbert, "The Left-Hand of Darkness" by Ursula K. Le Guin, and "Doomsday Book" by Connie Willis are a few examples which are double winners.) After many starts and stops over a 20+ year period, "Ender's Game" has finally graced the big screen. And it has been worth the long wait.The screen adaptation of "Ender's Game" is one of the best among classic science fiction novels. (By contrast, the original "Dune" film directed by David Lynch was an atrocious screen version of Herbert's famous novel.) Where "Ender's Game" succeeds (and the original "Dune" film didn't) was because the former understood the sensibility of the story. While on the surface, the plot seems simple: a young cadet is in training at a kind of military space school. At the same time, the story is much deeper than merely a bunch of kids playing shoot 'em up in a weightless battlefield. Underlying the setting of a training school for pre-teen space soldiers (written over 10 years before Harry Potter) is the idea of how a youth becomes a leader among his/her peers. Is leadership in-born, or is it taught? Or does it come from facing adversity in which the person must find within him or herself the ability to be self-reliant?The administrators of the space school don't believe that leaders are born, but rather can be forged, like a sword. And Earth needs someone forged for the task to stop the alien meanies who threatened to conquer earth. In the last battle, the meanies were stopped by a hero who had the guts and cleverness to use every resource available to ensure victory. To replicate their former hero, they contrive to offer one of their best students a series of experiences which will instill the idea that he is a leader. And that student is Ender Wiggin. The administrators in charge of his experiences are Harrison Ford and Viola Davis who put Ender through a ringer of impossible situations that would be nearly unbearable to almost everyone else. The story is not only about how Ender deals with these experiences at the training school but also how he grows into something a bit different than what the administrators had planned. And after having graduated to different levels of the training school, he meets someone he thought so much larger than life that he can't believe he has met him face-to-face.A beautiful and moving adaption of one of the great science fiction classics. The cast is first rate all-around with exceptional performances by the kids, particularly Hailee Steinfeld as Petra and the highest marks for Asa Butterfield as Ender. The special effects are fantastic, which is to be expected, but they support the story rather than overwhelm it, which seems to be the trend these days for most science fiction offerings. This is one of the few science fiction films that is simultaneously dazzling and moving. A rare find in the annals of SF filmmaking. And as stated by others involved with this film, the message of "Ender's Game" has absolutely nothing to do with the author's opinions on other subjects.
summary: Harry Potter Meets Star Wars: Excellent Adaption of One of the Classics of Science Fiction

reviewText: An OK movie, but ultimately the subtle message of the books and the internal struggles of Ender are hard to be conveyed in a short motion picture.  Knowing something of the books I was able to fill in the missing information for the most part, but I can see that if I'd known nothing this would have been very confusing. The lessons learned they showed did not have the desired response.Aside from not hitting the books very well, it was predictable, and not from my knowing the book standpoint, it was Hollywood predictable.  Not to mention within that scope a very weak finish.  Maybe the books and the recentness of them will help drive this for future, but box office losses in the millions do not make investors happy.  This movie had much more advertisement than recent box office Sci Fi flops such as Serenity, and Serenity was a much better movie based on the critics and fans who did see it.It's too bad, other movies like John Carter, had it preceded Avatar, had a better cast, and been named The Princess of Mars like the books, it might not have lost a ton at the box office.  Now all those other Edgar Rice Burroughs non-Tarzan books will take many more decades before someone decides to film one.  Enders will probably share the same fate.  All you can say now is try again someday.  It took nearly 50 years to make a good movie trilogy out of the Lord of the Rings despite many poor animated attempts, so there is still hope.  Not recommended unless you're just a fan who wants to own the only movie.
summary: Read the book, forget the movie, likely no more films will be coming soon for Ender, it's the cinematic END!

reviewText: The first time that I read Enders Game, I liked it. Fast track to many years later and my second reading and I felt that it was much less mature then my first read. Now to the movie, the attempt to be faithful to the book was excellent. It was not much of a problem to leave out certain sections that provided for the important description of the myriad pieces that helped one to understand the war and the novel process in selecting children to train with a brutal schedule that put boot camp to shame. Still, it was written for a younger population, younger then YA which in many cases is better written then adult level books. The ability to show the zero G training from the book was very difficult to transpose to the screen. Still, the cinema was artfully done and made the more juvenile story of interest to adult audience. I am always intrigued by the thinking and use of "out of the box" concepts. It is said that each war is fought with the weapons of the preceding war. This however showed that as important or of greater importance is fashioning of novel concepts that have not been used in the past.

reviewText: I'm not sure what I was expecting from this. I suppose I was hoping for Lord of the Rings: a sense of scale, emotional resonance, and characters so compellingly-realized that they replace the ones you mentally create when you read the book.Well, that's not this movie. It feels like a bullet point summary. There's no time to flesh anything out, so things just happen, point by point, with little glue or depth. Relationships and character motivations are so condensed that the emotional impact of many events just leeches away. Worth watching? Sure. It's not a bad spectacle and the plot is coherent enough. But comparisons to the source only highlight what it could have been.The outline hasn't changed. Ender's Game is set well in the future after an attack on Earth by an alien race. The military sends genius children (teenagers onscreen) with leadership potential to a 'battle school' in space to prove themselves against their peers. Some will eventually command a counterstrike. Ender is the most gifted and intelligent of the children, a 'chosen one' by adults under severe time pressure. How he adapts and how the others come to follow him comprise the majority of the book. The movie opts to excise much of this progression and a number of secondary characters. An open-ended epilogue leaves room for sequels.Ender himself is probably the biggest loss in the translation. He's intended as a tragic character. The crux of the book is that a person with the empathy to understand how to destroy this civilization would be too empathetic to do it, if he knew that he was. But he understands on some level, and as the pressure builds on him, so it does on the reader.That's amplified by the intense solitude Card imposes. In this movie, Ender is just another kid: fast friends with the others after minor goading. Not so in the book: he's small in stature and has only a moment to befriend Alai before he's accelerated away. The older children feel and prey on his sensitivity until his achievements transform him into an 'other,' a unicorn set apart by ability. And his superiors are never friendly. They think he has to believe that he's the only one capable of winning, and that no one will ever help him, or he won't see it through to the end. The fate of the world is literally in his hands and the weight of it nearly kills him.We don't get that sense of bleakness because it wasn't written into the script except at the final reveal (and as a result, Ender's response comes across as a tantrum rather than a moment of existential despair). It's a sort of generic teen-savior screenplay. That causes other problems. The challenge of adapting Ender's Game was always suspension of disbelief: how do you write child parts to make them seem deserving of adult responsibility? There's no disconnect on the written page because you're in Ender's head. You can see just how calculating and deductive he is. But very little of that is recreated. He acts like a normal, slightly precocious teenager, among other normal teenagers. In consequence, Harrison Ford's intense belief in Ender, prophetic in writing, seems a bit delusional here. If you can't accept the premise of child generals, it's difficult to appreciate the rest.What's left? To start, a capable lead. Asa Butterfield meshes well with the role, except insofar as the oddity of seeing a 5'1 adversary bully someone nine inches taller and twenty pounds heavier. He's actually better than Ford, who alternates between one-note gruff and hero worship. Viola Davis is underused. All the secondary characters could have been anyone. None except Petra have any meat to their roles. Ben Kingsley's Mazer Rackham remains a mysterious specter, perhaps the most interesting individual in the movie. One wonders if this couldn't have been a trilogy with the first third focusing on his exploits.And we've got some action with two major set pieces: a training 'battle room' much larger than what I'd envisioned, and an alien planet. Ender's initial experiences with the battle room in zero-G were the most engaging parts for me. It's one of the few sections where the movie slows to take a breath. As he experiences this new thing, so do you. That's pretty cool. By counterpoint, his later adventures commanding his proteges in a simulator were exciting enough, but terribly rushed and anticlimactic. The sense of scale is actually less than in the training scenes.On balance, Ender's Game is a decent film, but memorable to me more for the pain of what might have been rather than as a sympathetic reaction to the main character. I'd wait until it hits the discount racks. If you're viewing it with fresh eyes, you may have a better experience.
summary: Like having an ice-cream sundae in one bite

reviewText: I can't give it 1 star, simply because it looks like at least a modicum of effort was put into the design of the film, unlike most young adult book-to-film adaptations nowadays. However you could not lose the point or feel of the book more than this film does. They soften Ender's violent tendencies at every opportunity, in an ill-advised attempt to make him more sympathetic. Ender's violent outbursts are crucial to the story, and neutering him is detrimental. The changes to the finally are also perplexing in how they miss the point of the book and Ender's motivations. Just a waste. Not to mention the film is incredibly dull. Even if you're a fan of the book (or perhaps especially?) you can skip this one.
summary: As poor an adaptation as you're likely to find.

reviewerName: Darren Levine "He shoots, He Edits, He freque...
reviewText: It didn't help that i watched it with a bunch of friends, and we're all pretty critical, but we all had read the book as well.It started off OK, we all wanted it to be good, but went in expecting it to be just OK based on prior reviews.Too much in too little time:My feeling after watching it, was that i wished they would have either made it longer, or made chunks of the backstory as retrospect, whether it be in flashback or otherwise. As it is, it's just too rushed through and watered down from the book. "oh cool they're about to do that part, oh wait it's already past that..." happened numerous times. It's just rushed and no time is really given to anything.Spoon feeding whats happening:Another big complaint is that it's the same spoon fed crap 'storytelling' that hollywood does where they just tell you exactly whats going on instead of building up mystery/suspense/wonder/conflict/etc... that the book allows for. For instance, harrison ford tells ender RIGHT FROM THE DAMN BEGINNING that he's going to pit everyone else against him, and why. In the book, he doesn't know that, hes just confused as hell. spoon feeding, because we're all babbling babies that just wouldn't be able to comprehend things otherwise....The actingI was mostly fine with, maybe it's just me, but i can't take these kids seriously, and anytime they smile or have levity, i feel like im watching spy kids or something. one of the things im very happy they did was age them more, in the books they are a lot younger. can you imagine something like anakin from phantom menace being ender? dear lord i don't...An example of rushing things:When he goes to battle school, he spends time in several places, mostly in salamander group, and theres different ways he grows and excels, but in the movie it's literally him bouncing between things, and then all of a sudden he's trained the winning group and they're beating everyone. are you kidding me? at 37 minutes in, he can barely hit a target when the girl first takes him into the game field, and TWENTY minutes later at 57 minutes in, his dragon team defeats the other two teams. That's how much it's watered down/rushed through. I don't get a sense of this character growing at all.One more example of things being rushed:The video game he plays, it's a torment in the book, he comes back to it numerous times and as he grows, he figures things out about it. In the movie? nope, twice, done.Overall, i wish they just made some better choices in how to portray it. It isn't anywhere near the pile of garbage that became of Eragon, but i don't feel it does the book justice.
summary: It just had too big a shoes to fill, and it felt wrong on a number of levels

reviewText: I watched this at a friends house this weekend, and it was okay, a bit familiar, but confused most of my friends - I found myself explaining the parts that the director couldn't cram into the film. (Background: I've read the book before, and re-read it today) As it stands, the film is confusing to non-readers because it leaves out many of the motivations and explanations of some of the character motivations in order to fit the story into a feature length film.For those who are still interested in watching it but haven't read the book, here are some points that might help you enjoy the film more. (Or you could always read the book and get more out of it)  For those that haven't read the book - expect fast paced and "shallow" character development, with a touch of "what was that?" confusion.Character descriptions:Peter is Ender's brother; a cruel sociopath. The First child of a family, his online alter ego "Locke" is not shown in the film.Valentine is Ender's empathetic sister. The Second child of a family, her online pseudonym is "Demosthenes".Andrew "Ender" Wiggin is the main character. The Third child, he is engineered to be a balance of his brother and sister.Capt Graff (Ford Harrison) is a Captain in the International Fleet, who thinks Ender could be the future Admiral of the fleet.As far as the movie character Wiggin: I think the actor they picked had the right personality, but was too tall. The book repeatedly emphasizes how you and small he is, and untrained in fighting he is - especially in the physical fight scenes, while in the movie he teaches fighting to Petra.Missing background: the movie tries but fails to convey the fact that the Earth was badly hurt during the first invasion. So badly hurt that the Earth looked to genetic engineering to get faster, stronger, and smarter soldiers.  This little bit of knowledge might help you understand why the International Fleet has such power to draft a mere child out of a family. Also, the bit about First and Second: most families were limited to just one child, a few families earned the right to have a second child, but only in very rare cases were the right to have a Third child granted to families. All of there Wiggin children were bascially drafted before their parents were allowed to conceive. (In the movie he is "offered a place in the program")Ender is chosen to be a commander - Captain Graff hopes he will become the next Mazer Rackham, so Graff thinks it is best if he learns the isolation of command. This is why Graff singles him out on the first shuttle launch. Not shown in the film is a scene where the child sitting behind him keeps knocking him on the head until Ender grabs and breaks his arm. Also not shown is his later response where he cries in his bunk thinking back at this necessary cruelty.Upon arriving at Battle School, Ender is given the bunk closest to the door. Later in the movie it is explained that this is where "toon" (platoon) leaders sleep, because messages about the day's battle are slipped under the door. At this stage the "Launchies", as the newcomers are called, don't realize that they are assigning him this position. Not shown very well in the movie is Ender's struggle with Bernard - the book takes more time to explain how Bernard the bully gathers supporters to make Ender's life miserable. The movie does show the result in the cafeteria scene where the other children finally start to show support for Ender.The movie drastically shortens the series of training battles that Ender has against the other school's armies, and the way that the instructors make it more and more unfair against Ender until the final battle against two armies at once. (Never before heard of) The movie doesn't explain Bonzo Madrid's Spanish machismo very well - and in the movie I think Ender realizes he has killed Bonzo Madrid, the commander of the Salamander army; in the book he is rushed away and told only that Bonzo was "iced" (slang for failing out or being expelled from school) and sent back to Spain. Going back to the earlier fight on Earth - in that case the movie only says he put a child in the hospital; in the book he killed the child but doesn't realize it until much later.Command school is also drastically shortened and simplified in the movie, and doesn't cover much of Razer's lessons.  The movie glosses over "the reveal" that most of the recent improvements came from examining the Bugger's ships. They also did a poor job of showing Razer's battle scene - in the book there were multiple identical Bugger ships and Razer noticed that one seemed to be at the center of actions; the movie seems to show just a single attack on one enemy ship surrounded by drones. One thing I think the movie did better was explaining that the "Buggers" somehow got into Ender's computer-simulated world and used it to communicate with him.The Ending (PLOT SPOILER): It was a bit awkward how the movie revealed everything in a few seconds - how the graduation ceremony wasn't a training simulation; how he destroyed an entire alien race (The movie says "genocide" but it is actually xenocide); how he was responsible for the death of so many fleet soldiers; the revelation of the deaths of Stilson and Bonzo (the children he killed). Also, the movie puts the queen egg reveal on the "planet" Eros with Petra (Eros is the largest asteroid in our planet's solar system - chosen by the Buggers for an advance base); the book sets the stage for the next book by having Peter and Valentine emigrate to a new colony planet which looks strangely familiar - just like the computer-simulated world that Ender had back in Battle School.As I said before, I thought this movie was pretty good, but was distracted by the confusion of my friends, who had no experience with the book. So take that into account before buying this.
summary: For Orson Scott Card fans only

reviewText: I was very excited to hear that this was being made into a movie and when I saw the cast I was very hopeful. Sadly, so much is left out from the book there is very little left but a basic premise. I do not know if it was to much story for a single movie, and if that was the case they should have made it in two parts. Do battle school as volume one and command school as volume two. So much of the character development and the strategies were left out that it makes it almost impossible to understanding Ender and the other characters.  You get little snippets but nothing in depth, so when it all comes to an end it is very unsatisfying.The special effects were great, visually the movie looks good, and there are some nice moments, but as a whole it does very little justice to the source material.

reviewText: Where do I start? The theme of the movie is poorly set-up. You learn quickly about a privious alien invasion of Earth where millions of people died, but one brave pilot flying a standard military fighter jet defeated an entire alien force. Now, the aliens are expected to return and, this time, be successful, unless a young child (they have better intuition and responses--apparently from playing video games) is trained to lead unspecified forces against the aliens. Most of the movie involves us watching the training that occurs with a group of children and the type of exercises they go through to supposedly be prepared for a major alien attack is absolutely ridiculous and consists mainly of the children floating around a zero-gravity room and firing stun guns at other recruits. The whole story is asnine and Harrison Ford's performance is pure overacting--but it's not his fault because the script is shallow. Probably the most uncompelling sci-fi movie I've ever seen.

reviewText: The movie was slow and boring and... stupid. I am fan of sci-fi including the standard alien invasion genre but nothing here made sense. The few scenes with the aliens provide no clues to their society or motives. Somehow we are supposed to believe that hive-living colonial insects can build spaceships, and yet in the few scenes where we see the alien world there is no sign of technology- other than the spacecraft.  The authors don't seem to realize that in colonial insects genera the Queen does not "rule" (i.e. command) a society of essentially zombie drones. Instead each caste and each cast and each stage of each caste has functions-the adult Queen's function is to lay eggs, and that's about it- and the colony functions through the exchange of information ,generally in the form of chemicals and tactile communications,  and the colony functions in a very information DECENTRALIZED fashion. There is NO leader. As far as action scenes go, watch the trailer on You Tube- that's about all there it.  Even the final battle made no sense. Huge disappointment.

reviewText: Much better than I anticipated.First thing - it's based on the book but is not the book.  The 2-2.5 hour limit of a movie prohibits making a paragraph by paragraph recitation of the book.  HBO could do it perhaps, but not a movie.  Books turned in to movies always have this issue so if you expect the book on screen you will miss the movie.Second thing - it is not and never was a young adult, action-adventure, coming of age story in the fashion of Hunger Games.What is going on here are some deep and uncomfortable questions about belief and morality. Parents, schools, society and governments have always believed it is appropriate to mold children in a fashion beneficial to the collective whole. Even if it turns the child in to a useful monster?  Even if it merely leads the child into a adulthood he/she would otherwise reject?  Is it OK if survival of a society, nation of even the entire species is at stake?  If it is acceptable under the most extreme circumstances, what about when your total and sincere belief as to the actuality of said extreme circumstance is false?  Was it still OK because you genuinely believed?What about genocide? Is there any circumstance the justifies it?  What if the alternative is the certain extinction of your own culture or nation or species?  And again what if your true and genuine belief is false?  (The book was published thirty years ago when the Holocaust was much more in the memory of many still living.)What about a game or hyper-realistic simulation vs reality?  Do you make different choices depending on which one you face?  Should you?  What does it do to you when you think your actions don't count?Both the book and the movie are deeper than they first appear.  The more you can suspend disbelief and see yourself in the role of either the children or the adults the grimmer this tale becomes.

reviewText: Before reviewing “Ender’s Game” I need to summarize the plot for “The Last Starfighter” a 1984 movie. The prowess and tactic of a kid playing a video game becomes the last hope to save planet Earth; the kid is taken to a space-camp and he became the last starfighter. Okay now here is a summary of “Ender’s Game:” The prowess and tactic of a kid playing a video game becomes the last hope to save planet Earth; the kid is taken to a space-camp and he became the last starfighter. Wow, I didn’t have to change a single word? There is very little of this endeavor to be called original, except that the writing at the end is more humanitarian than the 1984’s sci-fi plot.There is also a terrible psychological side effect, which is turning video gamers into war heroes without accountability for sacrificing collateral damage, it is all part of the "game." The two stars goes for editing and acting, not much for originality.
summary: Copy of 1984's "The Last Startfighter" very little left for originality

reviewText: This movie is well made and decent enough as a movie although horribly rushed in pace, lot of big $$$ sci-fi special effects and blockbuster stuff, but they truly failed to grab fans of the book.  To me, the worst thing they did is make the kids way too old, which completely ruins the story.  The impact of the book is brought about by how incredibly young the children are, things that incredible at 6 or 8 years old don't mean much, are to be expected, creepy, or even seem juvenile when you are looking at a 16 year old.  I know the idiots in Hollywood think you can't have a movie if you don't have some hormonal eye candy prancing around - they even failed to do that.  They haven't created a heart-throb, they've spent 100 million dollars producing a flop that somehow managed to make a few dollars.The movie IS worth seeing, barely, but it could have been so much better.  The only way to have done this story justice would have been to break it down into two long movies or three two hour movies, and use actors the same age as those in the book.  This is not a teen romance, having the sexual tension thing with Petra and Ender was just plain wrong, and a waste of screen time.  Nemisis Bonzo Madrid, instead of being much bigger than Ender, is now a near midget homunculus, so big bad Ender is now killing a little kid whom he towers over, instead of being in any threatening situation at all???Too many dumb things about this movie to overlook.  I'm not sure I would have really even gotten a lot of the movie if I hadn't read the book about 20 times. Relationships were never established, character development was nil, If I didn't know who these people were from reading the book, I wouldn't have cared a thing about them. They could have added 10-15 minutes of character development to this movie and improved it dramatically, but it would still fail because Ender is an adolescent 16 year old from beginning to end, four years older than Ender was supposed to be at the very end.  The whole movie takes place with no aging of the characters, and the characters are slapped together in the same launch group. I rated it three stars, it's very generous.

reviewText: The premise of this movie is that moth aliens invaded earth 50 years ago, were narrowly defeated, and were sent back to their (or some other) planet. We are keeping an eye on them and it looks like they are running out of space. We've figured out that children, primarily tween boys, are the best at video games and interstellar combat. So far so good, pretty much works...Engaging plot and the acting is pretty good.Then this movie spends nearly the entire two hours with the main character, Ender, some other boys, and a token girl/puppy-love interest, going through various training camps, this goes on for probably 90 minutes. I felt the conclusion/battle/ending was rushed. Plus an intriguing side-story is underdeveloped of how, almost like a dream, Ender influences a video game he's playing on his iPad.There was an interesting Post Script Narrative that was thrown out at the very end - would have liked to see more on that too...maybe plans for a sequel?I think kids and scifi fans may enjoy this.
